description: From Middle English [Term?], from Old Norse ves heill (“be healthy!”), from the imperative of vesa (“to be”) + heill (“healthy”). The earliest documented use of the term is from 1275.

entries.meaning: A toast to health, usually on a festive occasion.
The beverage served during a wassail, especially one made of ale or wine flavoured with spices, sugar, roasted apples, etc.

examples: The victors abandoned themselves to feasting and wassail.

entries.meaning: A festive or drinking song or glee.

verbs.description: wassail (third-person singular simple present wassails, present participle wassailing, simple past and past participle wassailed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To toast, to drink to the health of another.
examples: The next morning he much regretted the gusto with which he had wassailed the night before.

entries.meaning: To go from house to house at Christmastime, singing carols.
examples: Schoolchildren around the globe have gleefully sung Torches at Christmastime for half a century. Many of those in Birmingham have wassailed the carol at the front door of a cosy Victorian house in Moseley, unaware that behind that front door lives its composer.
